---
name: readme-writer
description: Create and improve README files following best practices for structure, content, and documentation. Use when creating new READMEs, improving existing ones, or ensuring documentation completeness for open source projects. Includes GitHub-specific features like badges, shields, Actions integration, and advanced markdown.
---

# README Writer

This skill helps you create comprehensive, professional README files for GitHub repositories that effectively communicate your project's purpose, setup, and usage to users and contributors.

## When to use this skill

- Creating a new README.md for a GitHub repository
- Improving or expanding an existing GitHub README
- Adding GitHub badges, shields, and status indicators
- Leveraging GitHub-specific markdown features
- Ensuring README completeness and best practices
- Standardizing documentation across GitHub projects
- Creating README templates for repositories

## GitHub-Specific Features

### Badges and Shields

Badges provide at-a-glance information about your project. Use [shields.io](https://shields.io/) for custom badges.

**Essential Badges:**

```markdown
<!-- Build Status -->
![Build Status](https://github.com/username/repo/actions/workflows/ci.yml/badge.svg)

<!-- Version -->
![Version](https://img.shields.io/github/v/release/username/repo)

<!-- License -->
![License](https://img.shields.io/github/license/username/repo)

<!-- Code Coverage -->
![Coverage](https://img.shields.io/codecov/c/github/username/repo)

<!-- GitHub Issues -->
![Issues](https://img.shields.io/github/issues/username/repo)

<!-- GitHub Pull Requests -->
![Pull Requests](https://img.shields.io/github/issues-pr/username/repo)

<!-- Last Commit -->
![Last Commit](https://img.shields.io/github/last-commit/username/repo)

<!-- Contributors -->
![Contributors](https://img.shields.io/github/contributors/username/repo)

<!-- Stars -->
![Stars](https://img.shields.io/github/stars/username/repo?style=social)

<!-- Forks -->
![Forks](https://img.shields.io/github/forks/username/repo?style=social)
```

**Package Manager Badges:**

```markdown
<!-- npm -->
![npm](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/package-name)
![npm downloads](https://img.shields.io/npm/dm/package-name)

<!-- PyPI -->
![PyPI](https://img.shields.io/pypi/v/package-name)
![PyPI downloads](https://img.shields.io/pypi/dm/package-name)

<!-- Maven -->
![Maven Central](https://img.shields.io/maven-central/v/group-id/artifact-id)

<!-- NuGet -->
![NuGet](https://img.shields.io/nuget/v/package-name)

<!-- Docker -->
![Docker Pulls](https://img.shields.io/docker/pulls/username/image)
![Docker Image Size](https://img.shields.io/docker/image-size/username/image)
```

**Badge Organization:**

```markdown
# Project Name

<div align="center">

![Build](https://img.shields.io/github/actions/workflow/status/user/repo/ci.yml)
![Version](https://img.shields.io/github/v/release/user/repo)
![License](https://img.shields.io/github/license/user/repo)
![Coverage](https://img.shields.io/codecov/c/github/user/repo)

</div>
```

### GitHub Actions Integration

Show CI/CD status and workflow badges:

```markdown
## Build Status

| Workflow | Status |
|----------|--------|
| CI | ![CI](https://github.com/user/repo/actions/workflows/ci.yml/badge.svg) |
| Tests | ![Tests](https://github.com/user/repo/actions/workflows/test.yml/badge.svg) |
| Deploy | ![Deploy](https://github.com/user/repo/actions/workflows/deploy.yml/badge.svg) |
| CodeQL | ![CodeQL](https://github.com/user/repo/actions/workflows/codeql.yml/badge.svg) |
```

### GitHub-Specific Markdown Features

**Table of Contents (Auto-generated by GitHub):**

```markdown
## Table of Contents

- [Installation](#installation)
- [Usage](#usage)
- [API Reference](#api-reference)
- [Contributing](#contributing)
- [License](#license)
```

**Collapsible Sections:**

```markdown
<details>
<summary>Click to expand detailed installation steps</summary>

### Detailed Installation

1. Step one
2. Step two
3. Step three

</details>
```

**Syntax Highlighting:**

GitHub supports syntax highlighting for 500+ languages:

```markdown
\```javascript
// JavaScript code
const hello = 'world';
\```

\```python
# Python code
def hello():
    return "world"
\```

\```bash
# Shell commands
npm install package-name
\```
```

**Task Lists:**

```markdown
## Roadmap

- [x] Feature 1 (completed)
- [x] Feature 2 (completed)
- [ ] Feature 3 (in progress)
- [ ] Feature 4 (planned)
```

**Mermaid Diagrams:**

```markdown
\```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Start] --> B{Is it working?};
    B -->|Yes| C[Great!];
    B -->|No| D[Debug];
    D --> B;
\```
```

**GeoJSON and TopoJSON Maps:**

```markdown
\```geojson
{
  "type": "FeatureCollection",
  "features": [...]
}
\```
```

**Alerts and Callouts:**

```markdown
> [!NOTE]
> Useful information that users should know.

> [!TIP]
> Helpful advice for doing things better.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> Key information users need to know.

> [!WARNING]
> Urgent info that needs immediate user attention.

> [!CAUTION]
> Advises about risks or negative outcomes.
```

**Footnotes:**

```markdown
Here's a sentence with a footnote.[^1]

[^1]: This is the footnote content.
```

**Emoji Support:**

```markdown
:rocket: :sparkles: :tada: :white_check_mark:

See [full emoji list](https://github.com/ikatyang/emoji-cheat-sheet)
```

**Username and Issue Mentions:**

```markdown
Thanks to @username for the contribution!

Fixes #123
Closes #456
Related to #789
```

**Relative Links:**

```markdown
See [Contributing Guidelines](CONTRIBUTING.md)
Check [examples folder](./examples)
View [documentation](docs/README.md)
```

### GitHub Repository Settings

**Topics/Tags:**

Add repository topics through GitHub settings or README:

```markdown
**Topics:** `javascript` `nodejs` `typescript` `rest-api` `documentation`
```

**Social Preview Image:**

Create a 1280√ó640px image at `.github/social-preview.png` for social sharing.

**About Section:**

Mentioned in README but set in GitHub repository settings:

- Description (short)
- Website URL
- Topics/tags

### GitHub README Templates

**Issue Templates Reference:**

```markdown
## Reporting Issues

Please use our issue templates:

- [üêõ Bug Report](.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.md)
- [‚ú® Feature Request](.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.md)
- [‚ùì Question](.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/question.md)
```

**Pull Request Template Reference:**

```markdown
## Contributing

Before submitting a PR, please:

1. Read [CONTRIBUTING.md](CONTRIBUTING.md)
2. Follow the [PR template](.github/pull_request_template.md)
3. Ensure all tests pass
```

## Core README Sections

A complete README should include these sections in this order:

### 1. Project Title and Description

Start with a clear, descriptive title and a concise explanation:

```markdown
# Project Name

Brief one-sentence description of what the project does.

Optional: Add badges for build status, version, license, etc.
```

**Best practices:**

- Title should match the repository name
- Description should be 1-2 sentences explaining the project's purpose
- Include relevant badges (CI status, license, version, coverage)

### 2. Key Features (Optional but Recommended)

Highlight what makes your project unique:

```markdown
## Features

- üöÄ Fast and lightweight
- üîí Secure by default
- üåç Internationalization support
- ‚ú® Modern and intuitive API
```

### 3. Prerequisites

List requirements before installation:

```markdown
## Prerequisites

Before you begin, ensure you have:

- Node.js 18.x or higher
- npm or yarn
- Git
```

### 4. Installation

Provide clear, step-by-step installation instructions:

```markdown
## Installation

\```bash
npm install package-name
\```

Or using yarn:

\```bash
yarn add package-name
\```
```

**Best practices:**

- Include multiple installation methods if applicable
- Show version constraints
- Mention any system-specific steps

### 5. Quick Start / Getting Started

Show the fastest path to a working example:

```markdown
## Quick Start

\```javascript
import { PackageName } from 'package-name';

const app = new PackageName();
app.start();
\```
```

**Best practices:**

- Keep it simple and minimal
- Show the most common use case
- Make it copy-paste friendly

### 6. Usage / Examples

Provide detailed usage examples:

```markdown
## Usage

### Basic Example

\```javascript
// Code example
\```

### Advanced Example

\```javascript
// More complex example
\```
```

**Best practices:**

- Show multiple use cases
- Include code comments
- Explain what the code does
- Link to full examples in `/examples` directory if available

### 7. API Reference (For Libraries)

Document the public API:

```markdown
## API Reference

### `functionName(param1, param2)`

Description of what the function does.

**Parameters:**
- `param1` (string): Description
- `param2` (number, optional): Description. Default: `0`

**Returns:** Description of return value

**Example:**
\```javascript
const result = functionName('value', 42);
\```
```

### 8. Configuration

Explain configuration options:

```markdown
## Configuration

Create a `.config.json` file:

\```json
{
  "option1": "value1",
  "option2": true
}
\```

### Configuration Options

| Option | Type | Default | Description |
|--------|------|---------|-------------|
| option1 | string | "default" | What this does |
| option2 | boolean | false | What this does |
```

### 9. Development

Explain how to set up the development environment:

```markdown
## Development

### Setup

\```bash
git clone https://github.com/username/repo.git
cd repo
npm install
\```

### Running Tests

\```bash
npm test
\```

### Building

\```bash
npm run build
\```
```

### 10. Contributing

Guide contributors:

```markdown
## Contributing

Contributions are welcome! Please:

1. Fork the repository
2. Create a feature branch (`git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature`)
3. Commit your changes (`git commit -m 'Add amazing feature'`)
4. Push to the branch (`git push origin feature/amazing-feature`)
5. Open a Pull Request

Please read [CONTRIBUTING.md](CONTRIBUTING.md) for details on our code of conduct and development process.
```

### 11. License

Specify the license:

```markdown
## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for details.
```

### 12. Credits / Acknowledgments (Optional)

Recognize contributors and inspirations:

```markdown
## Acknowledgments

- Inspired by [project-name](https://github.com/user/project)
- Built with [technology](https://technology.com)
- Special thanks to [@contributor](https://github.com/contributor)
```

### 13. Contact / Support

Provide support channels:

```markdown
## Support

- üìß Email: support@example.com
- üí¨ Discord: [Join our server](https://discord.gg/xyz)
- üêõ Issues: [GitHub Issues](https://github.com/user/repo/issues)
```

## GitHub Best Practices

### Badge Placement

1. **Essential badges first**: Build, version, license
2. **Keep it minimal**: 5-8 badges maximum
3. **Group by category**: Build status, package info, community
4. **Use consistent style**: Choose one badge style (`flat`, `flat-square`, `for-the-badge`)

### README Length

- **Short projects**: 200-500 lines
- **Medium projects**: 500-1000 lines
- **Large projects**: Use table of contents, link to wiki/docs

### GitHub README vs. Documentation Site

**README should include:**

- Quick overview and installation
- Basic usage examples
- Links to full documentation
- Contributing guidelines
- License

**Documentation site should include:**

- Detailed API reference
- Comprehensive tutorials
- Architecture diagrams
- Advanced examples
- Migration guides

### SEO and Discoverability

1. **First paragraph matters**: GitHub uses it for search results
2. **Use keywords naturally**: Technology stack, use cases
3. **Add repository topics**: Up to 20 topics in GitHub settings
4. **Create social preview**: Custom OG image for sharing
5. **Link from other projects**: Cross-reference related repos

### README Analytics

Track README engagement:

```markdown
<!-- Add at bottom -->
![Visitors](https://api.visitorbadge.io/api/visitors?path=user%2Frepo&label=Visitors&countColor=%23263759)
```

### GitHub README Files

GitHub recognizes these special README files:

- `README.md` - Repository root (main README)
- `.github/README.md` - Alternative location
- `profile/README.md` - Organization profile
- `docs/README.md` - Documentation folder

### GitHub Profile README

Create a special repository with your username (e.g., `username/username`) with a README.md:

```markdown
<div align="center">
  <img src="https://readme-typing-svg.herokuapp.com?font=Fira+Code&pause=1000&color=2E97F7&center=true&vCenter=true&width=435&lines=Full+Stack+Developer;Open+Source+Contributor;Always+Learning" alt="Typing SVG" />
</div>

## üëã Hi, I'm [Your Name]

I'm a passionate developer interested in [interests].

### üõ†Ô∏è Tech Stack

![JavaScript](https://img.shields.io/badge/-JavaScript-F7DF1E?style=flat-square&logo=javascript&logoColor=black)

![React](https://img.shields.io/badge/-React-61DAFB?style=flat-square&logo=react&logoColor=black)
![Node.js](https://img.shields.io/badge/-Node.js-339933?style=flat-square&logo=node.js&logoColor=white)

### üìä GitHub Stats

[![Portfolio](https://img.shields.io/badge/-Portfolio-000000?style=flat-square&logo=about.me&logoColor=white)](https://yourwebsite.com)

### üëÄ Profile Views

![Profile views](https://komarev.com/ghpvc/?username=yourusername&color=blueviolet)
\```

**Profile README Features:**

- Animated typing effects
- GitHub stats cards
- Contribution streaks
- Activity graphs
- Trophy showcase
- Technology badges
- Social links
- Profile view counters

## Writing Style

1. **Be concise but complete**: Every section should be as short as possible but no shorter
2. **Use active voice**: "Run this command" not "This command should be run"
3. **Be specific**: Avoid vague terms like "easy" or "simple"
4. **Use consistent formatting**: Stick to one style of headers, code blocks, and lists

### Code Examples

1. **Make them runnable**: Every code example should actually work
2. **Add syntax highlighting**: Specify language in code blocks (`javascript`, `python`)
3. **Include imports**: Show all necessary imports/requires
4. **Show expected output**: When relevant, include what the code produces

### Visual Elements

1. **Use badges appropriately**: Only include badges that add value
2. **Add screenshots**: For visual projects, show the UI
3. **Create diagrams**: Use Mermaid for architecture diagrams when helpful
4. **Use emojis sparingly**: Can help with scanning but don't overuse

### Organization

1. **Use a table of contents**: For READMEs over 200 lines
2. **Group related sections**: Keep setup steps together
3. **Link to external docs**: Don't duplicate everything in the README
4. **Keep it updated**: README should match the current version

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

‚ùå **Don't:**

- Assume knowledge: Explain acronyms and technical terms
- Use relative time: "Recently added" becomes outdated
- Include outdated information: Update regularly
- Forget to test examples: All code should work
- Make it too long: Link to wiki/docs for detailed content
- Neglect mobile users: Ensure readability on small screens

‚úÖ **Do:**

- Test all commands and examples
- Keep language simple and inclusive
- Update when features change
- Make it scannable with clear headers
- Include a "Quick Start" for new users
- Link to additional documentation

## Template Structure

Here's a complete GitHub README template:

```markdown
<div align="center">

# Project Name

Brief one-sentence description

![Build](https://img.shields.io/github/actions/workflow/status/user/repo/ci.yml?branch=main)
![Version](https://img.shields.io/github/v/release/user/repo)
![License](https://img.shields.io/github/license/user/repo)
![Stars](https://img.shields.io/github/stars/user/repo?style=social)

[Features](#features) ‚Ä¢
[Installation](#installation) ‚Ä¢
[Usage](#usage) ‚Ä¢
[Documentation](https://docs.example.com) ‚Ä¢
[Contributing](#contributing)

</div>

---

## ‚ú® Features

- üöÄ Feature one
- üîí Feature two
- üåç Feature three
- ‚ö° Feature four

## üìã Prerequisites

- Node.js 18.x or higher
- npm or yarn

## üöÄ Installation

\```bash
npm install package-name
\```

Or using yarn:

\```bash
yarn add package-name
\```

## üéØ Quick Start

\```javascript
import { Package } from 'package-name';

const app = new Package();
app.start();
\```

## üìñ Usage

<details>
<summary>Basic Example</summary>

\```javascript
// Code example
const example = new Example();
example.run();
\```

</details>

<details>
<summary>Advanced Example</summary>

\```javascript
// Advanced code example
const advanced = new Advanced({
  option1: 'value1',
  option2: true
});
\```

</details>

## üìö API Reference

See [full documentation](https://docs.example.com).

## üó∫Ô∏è Roadmap

- [x] Initial release
- [x] Feature A
- [ ] Feature B
- [ ] Feature C

## ü§ù Contributing

Contributions are welcome! Please read our [Contributing Guide](CONTRIBUTING.md).

1. Fork the repository
2. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature`)
3. Commit your changes (`git commit -m 'Add amazing feature'`)
4. Push to the branch (`git push origin feature/amazing-feature`)
5. Open a Pull Request

## üêõ Issues

Found a bug? Please [open an issue](https://github.com/user/repo/issues/new?template=bug_report.md).

## üí¨ Community

- [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/user/repo/discussions)

</div>
\```

## Project-Specific README Types

### Library/Package README

Focus on:

- Installation methods (npm, pip, maven, etc.)
- API documentation
- Usage examples
- Version compatibility

### Application README

Focus on:

- Screenshots/demos
- Installation and setup
- Configuration options
- Running instructions

### Tool/CLI README

Focus on:

- Installation
- Command syntax
- Usage examples for common tasks
- Configuration files

### Tutorial/Learning Project README

Focus on:

- Learning objectives
- Prerequisites
- Step-by-step instructions
- Resources and references

## Checking README Quality

Before finalizing, verify:

- [ ] Title and description are clear
- [ ] Installation instructions work on a fresh system
- [ ] All code examples run successfully
- [ ] Links are not broken
- [ ] Grammar and spelling are correct
- [ ] Formatting is consistent
- [ ] Sections are in logical order
- [ ] Images/screenshots display correctly
- [ ] License is specified
- [ ] Contact/support information is provided
